15372.description: Guesstimation is a game all about educated guesses. For example, how many footballs can fit inside the Grand Canyon? The player guessing closest to the original amount, no matter how off they actually are, is allowed a bonus opportunity where he/she must determine the correct answer based on higher/lower promptings from the card reader.

15373.name: So you think you know about Ireland
15373.description:
This is a trivia game concentrating on Ireland: History, geography, politics, rumor, movies, folk tales, etc. The game consists of 104 cards (two of which detail the short rules). The cards have questions on one side of increasing difficulty, answering each of which correctly scores points (more points for harder questions). The difficulty progression is different on each card, so one card may have three easy, one medium and one hard question; while another may have two, two and one.

If a player cannot answer a question, the card has four multiple choice possibilities on the reverse for each question. Taking this option halves the points for a correct answer. Correctly answering allows you to keep being asked questions and scoring from the same card. A wrong answer has the card discarded and play passes to the next person.

The game has no given end conditions; either a fixed number of rounds or a time limit seem reasonable. Most points at the end wins.

15374.name: Valgkamp
15374.description: This is a political game in which you and your party tries to win an election using every means possible.

15375.name: Fyrtøjet
15375.description: This game is built on Hans Christian Andersen's children tale the tinder box. Each player is the soldier from the story and tries to win the princess and half of the kingdom by answering questions and roleplaying.

15376.name: The Lifestyle Game: Knowledge Deluxe
15376.description: A trivia game based on life style, fashion, design, art, wine, food, international trade, travel and luxury questions

15377.name: Danmark trivia game
15377.description: In Danmark trivia game you have 400 cards with 2400 questions from six categories : Miscellaneous, History, Sport, Culture, Nature and Geography. All questions concern Danmark only. Collect a token from each category to win. The players roll a die to move and then they must answer a question from the category they land on. If they answer correctly they get a token and when they've gathered tokens in every colour, they can head to the capital (center). First they need to get to a corner of the board where they answer a question of their own choosing. Then there are two coloured spaces from the corner to the center. When the players get to the center they answer a question of the other player(s) choosing. A correct answer in the center means victory!

15378.name: Danmarks Mester Junior
15378.description: Trivia game for kids with questions on Denmark

15379.name: Life is Ruff
15379.description:
From the instructions:

"Concept:

Life is a cycle of paychecks, bills and taxes that make it seem almost impossible to 'get ahead.' It has even been said that there are only two certainties in life...death and taxes. Today, of course, there is a third certainty...INFLATION!!

LIFE IS RUFF is about the cycle of income vs. outgo. As in reality, the proper investments can help you beat inflation and ride the waves of a fluctuating economy. In somewhat simplified terms, LIFE IS RUFF offers the player the same investment opportunities he has in real life and gives each player the opportunity to make investment decisions. But any opportunity not taken may be lost, for inflation hits when you least expect it.

There are those who will gamble, who will feel lucky, who will try to beat the odds and make a killing. For those we have included the stock exchange and futures market. There is a fortune to be made there, or lost. A player may choose to speculate in real estate, buy a home to get a tax break or keep his assets liquid by renting. All of these choices, and more, are yours and after all LIFE IS RUFF is only a game...or is it?

OBJECTIVE:

Each player attempts to obtain a survival package of items that have intrinsic value and are counter-cyclical to inflation. (Their value rises with inflation instead of declining.) Players, of course, must have cash to purchase these items (gold, silver, food storage, collectibles, diamonds, property) and the purchasing power of the dollar declines as the game progresses causing prices to "rise." The player who has the greatest number of survival assets (points) when RUNAWAY INFLATION strikes (making paper money worthless) is the best prepared and is the WINNER."

15380.name: The Game of CHIPS
15380.description:
The Game of Chips is a simple dice game from the makers of the Sequence. Components include a cloth bag for storage, poker chips numbered 1-10, a pair of dice, an instruction card, and one pad of preprinted score sheets. Play consists of three rounds of dice rolling and in which the ten numbered chips are placed in front of a player. The player then rolls the dice and removes any chip or combination if chips from play that equal the total on the dice. Repeat until no further chips can be removed. That player scores the total of the number of chips that have not been removed. Lowest score wins.

This game is very similar to Shut the Box, with the following differences:
- Any number of chips totaling the sum of the dice may be removed, not just one or two
- The game is played to three rounds rather than to 45 points.

15382.name: George of the Jungle
15382.description:
George of the Jungle fearless ape man! A protector of the weak and innocent, lurching through the tree tops he somehow outwits his opponents as he saves his friends...

This is a simple track game based on the animated TV show. The object is to reach George's Jungle House. On your turn you roll a die and advance around the board the number of spaces indicated. You may collect Elephant cards (that add or subtract from your die roll) by taking branch paths to tiger spaces. If you land on a Hazard space, you are stuck there until released by George. On your next turn, you roll the die and advance a George pawn down the George Track the number rolled. When he reaches your space you are freed. The first player to reach the finish space by exact count (Elephant cards help here) wins the game.

15383.description:
An association game. Draw a card with a word eg. a beach. name something on a beach an then it's the next players turn. You lose if you fail to come up with a word when the bomb explodes.

Similar to its older sibling Pass the Bomb this version is for younger players. Children will easily recognize the familiar scenes on each card.

In turn, each player has to think of an object that might be found in the picture on the card: for instance, if the scene is a beach, then perhaps 'sandcastle,' or ‘bucket,’ or even ‘whale’ might be good answers.

What makes this game a fun challenge is a time bomb which is passed to each player on their turn. Be quick, because the bomb goes off at a random interval somewhere between 10 seconds and 1 minute. If you are holding the bomb when it 'explodes', you have to keep the card. The player with the least number of cards is the winner!

Educational and great fun for kids. 2 or more players. Ages 5 and up

CONTENTS: 55 Game Cards, Rules, Electronic Bomb (Batteries Included).

NOTE: This Junior version is significantly different than the Regular version in that the Junior version does not have a randomizing die and it features picture cards rather than letter cards.
15383.name: Pass the Bomb Junior

15384.name: Goats on Boats
15384.description: Goats on Boats is a children’s memory matching tile game. The player that matches the most goats on boats pictured tiles wins. Game came be played solo, it also has several goat and boat facts on the back of each piece.

15385.name: Goodbye Mr. Chips
15385.description: This is a simple track game based on the novel. The object is to move through the boarding school to get to the assembly hall and graduation. On your turn, you roll the die and advance the number of squares indicated. When you reach the "Mr. Chips" space, you spin the "Mr. Chips" spinner sending you to a random board location. If you land on a Pompeii space you take an extra turn. The first player to get to the assembly hall, graduates and wins the game.

15386.description:
"From the SimplyFun website"

Eye to Eye™
Seeing the Same Never Looked So Different!

How closely do you see Eye to Eye with your friends and family? Draw a category card and write down three answers, trying to match at least one person for each item you write down. The person who matches the most answers with the other players will win the game!

Expanded by:

More Eye To Eye
Eye to Eye Junior
15386.name: Eye To Eye

15387.name: Keeper of the Estate
15387.description:
This game is part of a series ("#4 of a series")-- see Keeper of the Castle for #1 of the series. The rules on the box are rather difficult to understand, though they are brief. Figuring out what these rules mean would require attempting to play the game without understanding it at all. From the box, but really incomprehensible (grammar and spelling mistakes in the original!):

"2. - Player may take any item to start with but not jump or land on any item from then on.

3. - When an item lands on 'C' square player draws a card:
A. If own item place face up in front of player.
B. If an opponents item, give them the card which they place face up in front of them.
C. If card from position not being played place face down in discard pile.
D. If a Missed Payment card take item back to start.
E. If a Paid off Mortgage card take item to finish position. Home!
F. If you draw an opponents Open House card give them the card and you get 3 rolls of the die. (3 extra turns).

4. - The only time an item is safe is when the player has the card face up in front of them.

5. - The exact number must be rolled to get into the Bank as well as Home and if all items reach finish position before player has all their cards, they draw a card on their turn until they have all five cards. If a Missed Payment card or Paid off Mortgage card is draw, disregard and place in discard pile. If you draw an opponents card rule 3B applies and if an opponent draws your card Rule 4 applies and the item starts over.

6. - If all the cards are used up and there is no winner reshuffle the cards, place back in the Estate and continue following the above rules until there is a winner."

15388.description:
Memory game with a twist...
Who can remember where its animals are hiding? Flip three cards and see if you can find them!

Game components:
15 double-sided animal tiles
30 expedition cards (4 degrees of difficulty)
instruction sheet
15388.name: Safari Tours

15389.name: Sokrates
15389.description: Trivia game with questions based on philosophy.

15390.name: Harvest
15390.description:
This is the game to harvest your vegetables.

Begin with connecting field tile each other.
All completed vegetables in your field must be harvested even if it is rotten!

boardgameimplementation.15391: Death in the Trenches: The Great War, 1914-1918

15391.name: Death in the Trenches: The Great War, 1914-1918

boardgamehonor.10971: 2005 Charles S. Roberts Best DTP-Produced Boardgame Nominee

15391.description:
DEATH IN THE TRENCHES is a strategic-level World War I game covering the entire war, from the opening shots in Serbia and Belgium to the final defeat -- or victory! -- of Germany and Austria-Hungary in 1918. The game includes a map stretching from the Pyrenees to Moscow, and from Norway to the Sudan, covering every square inch of territory in Europe and the Near East which saw combat from 1914 to 1918, in a manageable 22x17 format. An additional map shows the German colonies

The game also features 308 beautifully-illustrated counters depicting the national armies that fought in the war -- from the Germans, French, British and Russians all the way down to the Persians, Montenegrins, Armenians, South Africans, and a host of other specialized units (French Foreign Legion, Gurkhas, Italian "Arditi", Cossacks, Tyrolean Kaiserjaeger, Zionists, Bavarians, "Dunsterforce"... even the Chinese may send a small expeditionary force).

DEATH IN THE TRENCHES includes a deceptively simple twelve pages of rules (and an additional twelve pages of random events) detailing the game's unique combat system (no CRT!) which portrays the grinding nature of World War I combat in a realistic way that still gives players plenty of options to pursue. Using army-level units (which contain numbers of divisional level formations, represented off-map), players use numerous special military abilities to drive back the enemy.

Detailed random events rules give you more gory details about World War I than you've ever seen before in a game, while helping keep play simple and straightforward. Lenin, the Senussi revolt, intrigue in the Romanian court, the Cruise of the Emden, the Armenian Massacre, the Sinai Pipeline, the Ukrainian Reactionary Hetmanate, Rasputin, Mata Hari, the Russian shell shortage, the murder of Edith Cavell, Wilhelm Wassmuss (the "German Lawrence"), Lawrence of Arabia, the Nestorian resistance, Pancho Villa, the Grand Duke Nicholas, Thomas Masaryk, the Red Baron, Czech Legion, Irish Rising, Berber Revolt, air raids, typhus, influenza... they're all here.

For the World War I buff, "DITT" has everything: Tanks, Alpenkorps, artillery barrages, flamethrowers, poison gas, Krupp guns, Mustapha Kemal, the Royal Air Force, French elan... while the great wartime leaders all leave their mark (good or bad!) on history: Bruchmuller, Haig, Hoffmann, Mackensen, Hindenburg and Ludendorff, Rennenkampf and Samsonov, Sarrail, Von Francois, Foch, Brusilov, Nivelle, Plehve, Putnik, Yudenich... they're all here. Players command the armed forces of nearly forty nations, in a game that still manages to be small enough to fit on your table!

It sounds like a massive game, but it isn't. DEATH IN THE TRENCHES is designed to be played--easy to play, hard to master. You'll learn things about World War I you never knew before, and you'll have to face the same crises the leaders of the Entente and Central Powers did. Think you can do better than Douglas Haig and Robert Nivelle? Now it's your turn.

Death in the Trenches won the Charles S. Roberts awards for Best DTP-Produced Boardgame (Charles S. Roberts Awards) for 2005.
15391.name: Death in the Trenches: The Great War, 1914-1918

15392.name: Intrigue
15392.description:
(From the inside box cover)

Intrigue is a fascinating game involving foreign agents, secret information and "murder." The action takes place aboard an ocean liner tied up at an American seaport. A diplomat courier has been murdered, and his briefcase, containing secret papers, has been stolen and hidden in one of the staterooms.'

'The object of the game is to be the FIRST DETECTIVE to locate the stolen briefcase and take possession of it. Clues are obtained by searching the staterooms and meeting opponents in the passageways of the ship.'

15393.description: Played with 10 "jacks" and a small rubber ball. Players take turns. On a player's turn, he must first throw the jacks onto the floor. If any of the jacks land so that they are stacked on top of each other, he forfeits his turn. Otherwise, he begins to pick the jacks up in groups. He throws the ball up in the air, and must pick up a group and catch the ball after exactly one bounce. A player must first succeed in picking up all 10 jacks one at a time in a single turn. Then he attempts to pick up the jacks two at a time, then in groups of three, and continuing on until he must pick up all 10 jacks in one group. If at any time, the player picks up the wrong number of jacks, touches any jacks not in the group, or fails to catch the ball, his turn is over. On his next turn, he will try again, starting with the same grouping.
15393.name: Jacks

15394.description:
Unlike many of the other Jax, Ltd. games, Takeaway doesn't seem to have previously existed as public domain.

Luck seems to play a heavy part in this game, advertised as "strategic": This is a set collection game, where you collect cards by making plays of cards between your cards and your opponents. At least, that seems to be how the game works: the instructions are well known to be less than specific.

The game seems to be well regarded by younger players, perhaps because they are not as concerned with playing by the "official" rules.

Verbiage from Jax, Ltd:
Take all you can get...when you play this unique, new family card game! Collect as many cards as you can by making plays between your cards and your opponent's cards. But BEWARE....Your opponents might take them all away! The player with the most cards at the end of the game wins!! It's challenging and fun. When you change comes, take all you can get and play Takeaway!
15394.name: Takeaway

15395.name: Bible Bingo
15395.description: This is simply bingo with a Christian theme. The caller randomly draws a cardboard chit and the players match its background color, pictures, and/or a Bible verse reference with like squares on their cards. Blank squares are provided to cover matches.

15396.name: Linkity
15396.description:
Every player starts with 7 cards and each card has a letter. The first player plays a card and announces a word that starts with that letter. Then any player can throw down another card as long as they can announce a word that starts with the letter on their card AND that has some relationship to the card previously played.

Poor associations can be challenged and players vote on the acceptance of the explanation. If the explanation is valid, the challenger takes two cards from the discard pile. If it is voted down, the player that played the card picks up two cards.

Once a player is out of cards, the round ends and each player scores the number of cards remaining in their hand. After three rounds, the player with the lowest score wins.

WHAT THEY'LL LEARN: Vocabulary, Quick Thinking, Word Association

15397.name: Sound Alikes A game using homonyms
15397.description:
The object of the game is to score the most points. Roll the dice to determine the order of play. The highest roll gives the clues first. There are 2 groups of words: one group has 2 homonyms and one group has three homonyms. The group of 2 is worth 10 points and the group of 3 is worth 20 points. Keep score on the points provided.

The player going first chooses a card with 2 homonyms and reads the clue to the player with the second highest roll of the dice. That player has 10 seconds to say the homonym. If he/she cannot, the next player in order has a chance etc. When that card is done the player with the second highest roll reads the clues to the other players. After all have read a clue with 2 words, a card with 3 is read.

The game ends when time expires (agreed upon) or when all the cards are read. The player with the most points wins.

15398.name: Fight Dice
15398.description:
Fight Dice is a freely downloadable PDF-based dice based combat system adapted for action figure battles. Players allocate (six-sided) dice from a pool for each action figure to allow for movement and/or combat. Combat consists of sets of dice rolled for attack and defense (as allocated,) defense dice that are equal or higher cancel attack dice, the number of remaining attack dice are removed from the defender's dice pool. Movement is one inch for each die allocated to movement. Advanced rules allow for enhanced movement/range mechanics, foreign objects, grappling, etc.

The game guidelines state that a standard human gets 8 dice, a martial artist 20 and a Gundam Fighter gets 36. Players are encouraged to use their imagination to assign values to action figures.

15399.name: Kharkov 1943: le coup de maître de Von Manstein
15399.description:
This game is a two in one as it contains all the material for TWO battles of World War 2: Kharkov (1943) and Rostov (1941) both happening in the same corner of USSR.

A fourth game of a planned series of six which all use the same rules, on 6 page leaflets. Published in a issue of Casus Belli and then used for a wargame tournament, the last two of the series never saw the light of day. Each game containing the global rules and a sheet of paper with the specifications for the scenario. Three of those 6 games were published by EuroGames: Moskva, Kharkov(Rostov) and Kursk.
Strategical scale: Battalion, Division, Army Group.

A turn is 4 days long, an hex represents around 10kms.
The battle centers around tanks, but Infantry and Cavalry are an important element. Planes and Artillery are simulated with points which affect the game.

Weather affects combat and movement as both battles (Kharkov and Rostov) happen in autumn/winter. Russian forces are better prepared for the weather conditions, while German forces are better equipped.

Victory is gained by destroying opposing troops and conquering towns to score Victory Points.

15400.name: Main Street
15400.description:
This game has a series of 5 different games for players of varying ages.

From the rules:

"Like its predecessor, GOOD OLD HOUSES, this game focuses player attention on specific architectural details and on the stylistic variety of historic buildings. MAIN STREET, however, brings attention to downtown buildings, structures which, in the hustle and bustle of commercial life, escape the notice of even frequent passers-by. Our illustrations show each style with its original storefront, but because storefronts are periodically remodeled, one is lucky to find historic storefronts intact. MAIN STREET players will find themselves looking at the upper levels of commercial buildings to recognize styles they have learned in the game.

The range of styles in MAIN STREET from Federal to Art Deco/Modern, isn't intended to encompass the breadth of American Architectural history, but to represent some basic styles often used in commercial buildings between the late eighteenth and mid-twentieth centuries.

The eight building puzzles (nine pieces per puzzle) are used in five different games for 1 to 8 players Ages 5 and up."

15401.description:
Space Hulk Campaigns is a book containing additional missions and rules that greatly expand and enhance the popular Space Hulk game system. This is not a complete game. Copies of Space Hulk and both the Space Hulk: Deathwing Expansion and Space Hulk: Genestealer Expansion expansions are required to play all of the campaigns within the book.

This 85 page hard backed book includes 24 new scenarios which can be played stand-alone or as four complete campaigns. A campaign is a linked series of between four and six missions where the outcome of each mission affects the overall chance of success in the campaign.

The included campaigns are:

The Last Stand
Four linked missions where four Space Marine squads attempt to defend an Imperial outpost from Purestrain and Hybrid infestation. Can they hold out until the relief garrison arrives?

Genestealer Invasion
Six linked missions. The Terminators and Librarians of Septimus V attempt to destroy a Genestealer patriarch deep inside the body of a crashed Space Hulk.

Necromunda
A clever set of six linked missions split into two waves. The Marine player gets to choose squads of Marines and Librarians from “army lists” and must first contain the Purestrain and Hybrids, then discover and exploit their weakness for total victory.

Sentinel V
Four linked missions split across two levels where six squads of Terminators attempt to locate and destroy a Patriarch guarded by Purestrain and Hybrid Genestealers
The book also includes a host of new rules including Space Marines in power armor (ie “normal” non-Terminator Games Workshop Space Marines,) rules for crack, frag, plasma, blind and melta grenades and rules for Traitor Terminators.

Games Workshop figures for Space Marines in power armor and Traitor Terminators are required to play the expanded rules for these units.

Expands:

Space Hulk
Space Hulk: Deathwing Expansion
Space Hulk: Genestealer Expansion
15401.name: Space Hulk Campaigns

15402.name: Metropolis
15402.description:
Long flat box, only two pages of rules. Drive cars around a city (roll a die to move) and purchase building lots of various values (green - highest, yellow - middle, red - lowest) and types (plaza, industrial, apartment, municipal, business). Hard board map depicts building lots, and various movement effect spaces (stopping arrows in different directions and configurations) - you collect money and can change direction of movement). When you purchase the lot you take the card for that lot.

You subsequently build on those lots based on certain restrictions (eg. 3 undeveloped residential lots can be built over if you buy a plaza lot). Subsequent activities include auctioning, mortgaging, trespass fines.

Pretty basic looking as a game. Out of print.

Contains 48 plastic buildings.

15403.name: Data Boxing
15403.description:
Data Boxing features yesterdays legends and hall of famers reflecting the glory days of years gone by. You'll find Ali, Marciano, Dempsey, Louis, Tunney, Foreman, Frazier, Baer, Braddock and more.To quote the designer of the game, Dr. Julian Compton, from a Data Boxing Newsletter (in 1977), "One of the real thrills for this game player is to see the stars of the past come alive in a game structure. Usually these names will be familiar, but ever so often an unknown will rear his head in a bid for greatness."

Data Boxing is "the boxer's Boxing Game". It's a detailed, realistic simulation of boxing where boxers of all eras are matched. There is a real component to it because it's based on the actual performance of boxers. Individual fighters are rated on cards, and bouts are resolved through dice and charts and/or rounds cards (see Data Boxing II below).

Data Boxing is based on decades of study and research. It began as a research project in 1967 by humanities professor and boxing authority, Dr. Julian Compton (1940-2010). The heavyweights were evaluated on up to 155 variables. The table game first appeared in 1976. The computerized version was first released in 2004 which is set up similarly to the board game. The computer implementation was done by NASA programmer Don Mankowski. Data Boxing was featured in the December 1977 edition of Ring Magazine, The People's Almanac [1978], Computer Sports Match-ups [1981] and in the December 13th, 2006 issue of the Tallahassee Democrat.

15404.name: Program IV Baseball
15404.description: Small game designed to simulate professional baseball, consisting of just eight pages of rules and charts. No teams were included with the game, but rather instructions to rate teams based on real-life statistics. Games were then played with dice and the charts provided.

15405.name: Program IV Football
15405.description: Small game designed to simulate professional football that consisted of just eight pages of rules and charts. No actual teams were included with the game, but rather instructions to rate the teams based on real-life statistics, such as yards per carry and completion percentages. Games are then played using dice and charts to resolve plays.

15406.name: Chicken Soup For The Soul
15406.description: (For 2-6 players or team play-Ages 9 and up) Inspired by the #1 Bestselling Books! Chicken Soup for the Soul The Game. It's "Condensed Soup Recipe" for gameplay- 1. Pick a card, 2. Roll the die, 3. Do what the card says to collect a card and to move your token. The game consists of the following "ingredients": 1 game board, 200 cards (4 decks in different colors), 6 tokens, 1 pencil, 1 pad, 1 Chicken Soup die, 1 tsp. of humor, pinch of wisdom, dash of friendship, a generous portion of love. The object of the game is to be the first player to collect 8 cards, 2 from each deck. And while you're doing that enjoy the experience of sharing, friendship and laughter.

15407.name: TATATA!
15407.description:
TATATA! is a simple, funny, complete card game that allows 8 crazy pilots to fly for victory in a "dogfighting race" where many weapons and strange tools may be found in the cards that form the circuit in the sky.
Memorize the circuit due the race is on 3 laps, stop in the good cards, avoid the bad ones and mostly avoid to stop in front of the guns of another plane or it will TATATA! you!
Basic Rules are good also for younger gamers and children. Complete Rules allow to use one of the 4 numbers at your choice on each Deck Card.
Choose how many cards play with the "Action" value, then Move, Fly, Looping and... TATATA!

15408.name: Gülle Gülle
15408.description:
From the rules:

Players buy cows and fields. The cows produce fertilizer. Fields can be fertilized with the fertilizer. The fertilizer helps the corn to grow. Each player tries to harvest as many ears of corn as possible. Corn is the means of payment for additional resources - and is worth victory points at the end of the game.

15409.name: Kon-tiki
15409.description:
Kon-tiki is a game that casts players as the crew of a raft as it makes an epic journey across the Pacific Ocean from Peru to a Polynesian island (re-enacting Thor Heyerdahl's voyage in 1947). A competitive atmosphere is in place as the players bid to prove their worth on the journey by accomplishing Duties and navigating through whirlpools.

A network of arrows make up the routes from start to finish. Each player equal numbers of counters (of all colors); they move the raft up to 3 arrows (and only along their direction) on their turns by using up counters of the same color as shown on the last whirlpool traversed (the initial departure from Peru can use counters of any color). When the raft moves onto a whirlpool, it must stop there. The active player receives a Navigational Certificate and changes the direction of the whirlpool's arrows and its color. Aside from these certificates, players can receive Duty cards if they land the raft on an arrow that is connected to the Duty tiles placed on the board.

The game ends when the raft reaches the island of Raroio. The players sum up the points given for their Navigation Certificates and sets of Duty cards. The winner is the one with the most points.

boardgamehonor.8858: 2006 Golden Geek Best Kids' Board Game Nominee

15410.description:
"From the SimplyFun website"

Walk the Dogs™
Unleash 63 Miniature Dogs That Won't 'Flea' From Your Table

Grab a leash and get ready to Walk the Dogs! Each player collects dogs from the front or back of a long line by drawing and playing cards. But, beware of the dog catcher who may steal some of your favorite dogs. To win, collect five of the same breed in a row, or have the most dog points in your own line. Woof!

What breeds come in the game?
Poodle, Pug, Brittany Spaniel, Shitzu, Scottish Terrier, Golden Retriever, and Pomeranian...and they're all rescue dogs!

Includes:
63 Miniature Dogs in 7 different breeds
53 Cards - 18 red, 18 green, 6 yellow, 3 dog catchers, 5 bones and 3 leashes
1 "Doggie Bag"
2 Score Sheets
1 Instruction Booklet
1 FunMemories™ Booklet

WHAT THEY'LL LEARN: Counting & Early Multiplication, Risk & Reward
15410.name: Walk the Dogs

15412.description:
"From the SimplyFun website"

Tunebaya™
No Previous Singing Experience Required

You Ain't Nothin' But a Hound Dog! — Did you just sing that out loud? Yes, and so did everyone else. When other players sing along, you and the other players score points. Match a song with someone else and score the big bonus. Everyone join in and sing Tunebaya!

Includes:
100 Double-Sided Topic Cards
7 Small Microphones
1 Large Singing Microphone
8 Pencils
8 Scoreboards
1 Pad of Answer Sheets
1 Instruction Booklet
1 FunMemories™ Booklet
15412.name: Tunebaya

15414.name: Tee It Up
15414.description: Tee it up- the funtastic game of golf for 2-6 players is a roll and move game that consists of 3 dice- blue driving dice, green fairway dice, yellow putting dice, tee markers, bonus trap pass cards, sand trap cards, a pad of score sheets, pencil, wooden trophy and game board. The object of the game is to roll and move along the gameboard adding up strokes for each hole along the way and end the game by being the golfer with the lowest number of strokes. Winner takes the trophy. Scoring is determined by "tee-offs", "fairway shots", "putting shots", and "obstacles". NOTE: This game also features a "Sudden Death" playoff to break any ties. "Sudden Death" playoff is agreed upon between golfers aka players and then three consecutive holes on the gameboard could be selected for this purpose. Lowest number of strokes wins.

15415.name: Decoy: A Game of Chance
15415.description:
A children's game that imitates duck hunting-
Retrieve ducks for high score!
Object of the Game is to close blind by placing 8 ducks on the lake. To place two decoys on the lake and to refill 'the blind' with 8 ducks to end the game.

Game contents includes the following:
1 red and 1 green die
8 each white, green, black, yellow Ducks
8 Red Decoy Ducks
1 playing board
Instructions

15416.name: Cowboys and Indians
15416.description: COWBOYS AND INDIANS board game for young players. Build a Corral, Capture a Pony. The directions are 2,3, or 4 may play, each playing from a Cowboy or Indian "corral" as selected, with colored sticks to match. Each player spins in turn. The first player spins the arrow. It if points to a pony, the player places a pony in his own corral. If the arrow points to a color, the player holding sticks of that color, places one stick in his own corral, no matter who did the spinning. This continues in turn until one corral has been completely fenced in. Then all the players count their ponies and the one having the most is the winner.

15417.name: Championship! Show Jumping Game
15417.description:
CHAMPIONSHIP, "The Most Authentic Show Jumping Game" from Capri, dated 1975.

CHAMPIONSHIP SHOW JUMPING captures the atmosphere, the skills and excitement of international show jumping, making a gripping and absorbing game for all the family."

The contents of the game include-

base board
instruction manual
two wall brackets
six different horses
17 jumps or obstacles
scoreboard to record moves and faults
penalty zone cards
leader score card

15419.name: Happy Families Picture Card Game Jerusalem
15419.description:
"Made in Israel", the rules sound very similar to the American version of "Go Fish".

(40 card deck) Deal four cards to each player, and place the remaining cards face down on the table, as a "pool". Each player examines his cards and arranges them according to series, discarding any complete series.

The aim of each player is to collect four cards of a series.

The first player asks any one of the players to give him a card, which he needs to complete a series. He may not ask for a card unless he holds one or more of the series. If the person who has been asked, has the card in his hand, he must hand it over, and the first player continues to ask for further cards. If the person asked, does not possess the card, the first player picks a card from the "pool" and the person asked continues to ask for a card in the same way.

The winner is he who has the largest number of completed series at the end.

15420.name: Thirteen
15420.description:
Advertised in Life Magazine- An educational game tool for young and old alike that teaches or improves math skills (multiplication tables). Tile placement game that includes gameboard and several numbered individual wooden tiles and instructions.
(Game design similar to "Scrabble".)

The box reads: "Have Fun with the Multiplication Tables And Develop Your Mental Muscles At The Same Time."

15421.name: The Deputy Game
15421.description: Ages 7 - 14 "THE DEPUTY" This game was fashioned after the TV series that ran from 1959-1961. The box cover features HENRY FONDA who played the role of Chief Marshall Simon Fry, and ALLEN CASE, who played THE DEPUTY. Game components consist of the game board, 4 player tokens, instruction board and spinner, three sets of cards and dice, and the Marshall's badge. Marshall's badge is awarded to the winner of the game.

15422.name: Coober Pedy
15422.description:
This gemstone collectible game was manufactured in 1974 by Opal Syndicates LTD. in Adelaide South Australia.
A mining game that consists of 4 genuine opal counters, playing board with story and glossary, rules for playing the game, 20 opal strike cards, bank notes, 20 machinery tiles, 34 good luck cards, 20 bad luck cards, card and money holder.

15424.name: Zombie Hospital
15424.description:
Stuck in a hospital with flesh eating zombies Barry must find his way out before the zombies eat him.

8 weapons to protect your self from the zombies including
12 ga. shotgun,357. magnun, 9mm.and more.

4 levels of terrible horror to find your way out.

15426.description:
This is a bizarre racing game that uses a "Play Dough" like substance to to create worms. Before the game begins, the players use plastic molds to cookie-cut "Grubs" out of the dough and place them into a mutual pile. The racetrack consist of two side-by-side plastic tracks with a finish line at one end and two plastic plungers (shaped like tree stumps) at the other (one for each player's track).

On your turn, you roll the die to either race or chomp a worm. If you roll a 1-4, you place the number of grubs indicated into your tree stump and press down the plunger. The dough is mashed and forced out the base in a continuous worm shape over the track. You attach a wheeled worm head to the tip of the dough and add side wheels as needed to support your worm's body. Thus the worms get longer and longer as the race progresses. If you roll a Mr. Chomp, you take a bird shaped device, chomp off the head of your opponent's worm, then place the chomped segment into your tree stump to move your worm ahead. Your opponent must then reattach the plastic worm head to the remainder of his or her worm segment.

The first player whose worm grows the entire length of the track, crosses the finish line, and takes the checkered flag is the winner.
15426.name: Go! Go! Worms

15427.name: The Worst-Case Scenario Survival Card Game: Travel Edition
15427.description:
Based on The Worst-Case Scenario Survival Handbook, this "travel edition" of the game is a single pack of 55 cards with 108 questions. This game is intended for use as an expansion to the board game of the same name or as an independent travel edition of the game.

The game is a very straightforward trivia game, where one person reads the questions to another player until that player can no longer answer one correctly. The first player to answer 5 questions correctly wins.

15430.description:
Marignan 1515 is a simulation of the great battle between the army of Francis I, King of France and the mighty Swiss army during the Italian Wars.
The French army is a combination of cavalry, artillery and infantry, while the Swiss army is a new reincarnation of the Macedonian phalanx.

Two scenarios are covered: the first is set only during the first day of the battle, and the second simulates the two days of the engagement with the reorganization of the armies during the night.
Both players objective is to rout or completely destroy the opposing army.

The game includes one map, rules, unmounted counters and game charts.
15430.name: Marignan 1515

15431.name: Trivial Pursuit: Globetrotter
15431.description:
The six categories are now replaced with six regions:

North American
Latin American (includes Mexico and South America)
Oceania
Africa
Europe
Asia

15432.description:
Pour Dieu et Pour le Roy (For God and the King) simulates the war in the Vendée, France 1793, a period poorly covered in games in general.

A game turn is one month (March 1793 to October 1793).
One point of combat represents 500 to 1500 men.
The map represents the Vendée (West coast of France, under the Loire river) and is divided in areas of roughly 10 x 10 kms.

One player controls the republican troops, while the other controls the revolting people of the Vendée.
15432.name: Pour Dieu et pour le Roy

15433.name: Goldrake all'attacco
15433.description:
Children game from Mattel based on the popular giant robot Grendizer (Goldrake in Italy).
Players race against each other trying to defeat the enemy robot and the final spaceship.

The movement is driven by a classic spinner and combat is resolved by cards with Rock-Paper-Scissors mechanic.

Contents:

1 Map board
1 Spinner
4 Plastic counters
6 Enemy robot weapon cards
24 "Goldrake" weapon cards
4 Templates for enemy robot weak points filled with puzzle pieces
(Rules printed on the back of top cover box)

15434.name: Le Tour de France
15434.description:
This is the predecessor of "Homas Tour", aka "Um Reifenbreite".

Each team managers receives at the start of the game 3x frs. 10,- and 2x frs. 5,-.
At the start you move the racers normally as indicated by the dice. At the next turns however you must pay great attention. On the track are places with a special sign (green star, red circle, etc). Some of these places give an advantage, others a disadvantage to the racer who is placed on it. It is your job as a team manager to try and place your racers as much as possible on the advantage places and to try and avoid the disadvantage places.

Each team manager should have a list as shown on the backside of the Table for time trial. This list is called the Yellow Jersey Standings.The racers who had the most points in the Yellow Jersey standings, is allowed to wear the yellow jersey (the yellow plastic cap is put over this racer) and he receives an additional fee of frs. 40,-.

End of the Tour
The end of the sixth stage is exactly the same as the end of the other stages, but only the racer who now wins (or keeps) the yellow jersey is the winner of the Tour and he receives now a fee of frs. 100,- instead of the usual frs. 40,-.
There are three ways to win the game:

New divison
This is the fastest and most simple way, also suitable for children. In this variant one only plays for the Yellow jersey standings. No money is used and the Green jersey score is not kept. The normally quite long playing time is now considerably shorter. At the end of each stage only the points for the Yellow jersey standings are written down and the corresponding racers receives the yellow jersey.
The winner of the tour is the one, who has the yellow jersey at the end of the Tour.

Amateurs
In this variant money isn’t used either (so no fines and/or fees). For both standings are the points written down, so the yellow and green jersey come into play. In both standings will be a winner at the end of the Tour.

Professionals
This is the Tour de France game in its most beautiful and most complete form. In this variant you use: the Yellow jersey standings, the Green jersey standings and the Banks handles all money affairs such as starting fees, race fees fines, etc. This way of playing costs more time then the two previous ways and it will take about 2 or 3 hours.

15435.description:
From publisher:
Stand by for the hottest action in 30mm science fiction gaming. Released in late March, Starship Troopers will bring the action of the novel, film and TV series straight to your tabletop in a fast-to-learn wargame.

Do you want to know more?

Collect armies of the Mobile Infantry, Arachnids and Skinnies (and that is just for starters - there are far more aliens out there in the galaxy!) and compete for the very survival of your species.

Written by Andy Chambers, the all new Starship Troopers miniatures game is a full blown sci-fi slaughter fest pitting the rugged Mobile Infantry against the full weight of the Arachnids. This box set provides everything you need to get started in the Starship Troopers game and includes;

A complete rulebook detailing both basic and advanced rules, as well as background material on the universe of Starship Troopers.

20 plastic Arachnid Warrior Bugs, a good start to any full size Arachnid army.

2 Squads of 8 Mobile Infantry Cap Troopers each with full weapon options including Javelin missile launcher Triple Thud grenade launcher, Hel infantry flamer, CC-176ER shock stick and, of course the trust Moritas rifle.

More punch out templates than you can shake a dead Hopper Bug at! Includes Tunnel Markers, Bug Nests, Lethal Zones and complete air support, such as Flamberge support missiles, Viking transports and TAC Fighters.

A complete card Bunker, ready to protect your MI in defensive missions. You will come to value this structure dearly. . .

Full army lists detailing everything we plan on releasing for both Arachnids and Mobile Infantry this year. You will not have to wait for an update to start using units such as Marauders, Tanker Bugs, SICON Observers, Hopper Bugs and many others.

It's a battle for the species - whose side are you on?
15435.name: Starship Troopers Miniatures Game

15436.name: Sleep Over Club: Goof or Dare Night
15436.description: This is a truth or dare party game for girls. The player whose turn it is (called the Goof) is asked, "Truth or dare?" The Goof selects a category and is read a question from a card. She must answer the question truthfully or else perform the task described at the bottom of the card. Both questions and tasks are designed to be silly. If the group decides that the Goof did a good job, she receives a bead from that category for her bracelet. By the end of the game, each player should have three beads from each category on their bracelets. Winning and losing is not really important since the game is designed mainly for slumber party fun.

15437.name: Goofy Go-Along Games
15437.description: This game for young children is actually four games-in-one, and deals with the Disney character Goofy trying to build a clubhouse. In the first game, the cards are laid out face up on the table and the players race to pair up things needed for building: hammer and nails, paintbrush and paint bucket etc. The second game is a simple card matching game. For game #3, players take turns turning up cards trying to build complete set of building tools. For game #4, a player tries to guess the missing tool by asking questions like: "Does it have a handle?" Players are encouraged to design their own games using the cards.

15438.name: Goosebumps: Cool Ghoul Card Game
15438.description: The object of this Goosebumps themed game is to get rid of all your cards. The cards are dealt out evenly to all the players and kept face down. On your turn, you flip over your top card into the middle of the table. The cards feature Goosebumps characters and all players must simultaneously respond to the picture of the card just flipped such as: The Werewolf--tilt your head back and howl, Slappy--the last player to slap the pile takes the pile, Mud Monster--hold your nose, The Horror--do nothing. If all players do the right thing, the next player flips his or her card onto the pile. If someone goofs, that player takes all the cards on the table. Get rid of your stack of cards first and you win.

15440.name: Ordet på bordet
15440.description:
From the publishers web page:
A fast word cardgame for two or more players from Ages 10 and up.

15442.name: Spas-mager
15442.description: Roll the dice and move on a board, but on the way to the finish line you will have to draw "acting card" that tells you what to do in order to proceed.

15443.name: Eventyrspillet
15443.description: Based on the fairy tales of Hans Christian Andersen this game lets you discover eight of his tales.

15444.name: The World's Educator
15444.description:
One of the first formal "Trivia" games of the late 1800's Very ornate wood box with numerous cards with questions covering several different topics.

This game reflects the heavy religious sentiment of the era and has a unique mechanism for gameplay. Each question is assigned two letters. The letters are matched up on the spinning cylinder within the box and are given a corresponding 2 digit number. The number is located on the question card and that reveals the answer! This appears to be one of the first games where expansion sets were available as well. A player could purchase additional question cards for $0.05 each or $0.50 for a dozen.

W.S. Reed Toy Company was located in Leominster, Massachusetts.

15445.name: History Up To Date
15445.description:
Trivia card game based on historical events developed by Parker Brothers in the 1890s. Expansion cards were available for this game.

Interestingly many of the cards and questions contain spelling errors. If you do not know historical events of the 1800's. You might want to brush up before playing this game!

15446.name: Hearts: An exciting Letter Game
15446.description:
A six Dice game containing the letters that spell H-E-A-R-T-S on each side of each die. Each player rolls the dice once and scores based on how many letters of the word hearts are rolled. Each letter after the H is counted as 5 points. 4 H's rolled doubles your score and 4 S's cancel your score.

Strongly based on luck, Players compete to a predetermined point goal of 100 or 200 or whatever is agreed upon.

15448.name: I'm a Millionaire
15448.description:
A great economical card game from the turn of the century. The instruction sheet reads "The best game since PIT" on the front.

Cards are passed between players as players try to collect complete circles of related society members. Cards have comical names of people within a society, they could call them cliques rather than circles. (examples: Mrs. Get-there, from Butte, Mr. Clymer from Denver and Major But-in (the character who disturbs the social gatherings)) Each circle has a monetary value associated which is paid to the player who collects the entire circle and turns it in to the bank. The player with the most counters (Counters represent $50,000 each) at the end wins the game.

The rules are very specific and proper etiquette is enforced!!

Typical of the time, early games were designed with religious backgrounds encouraging high sense of morals and etiquette.

15449.name: Um El Bagara
15449.description:
Also known as "The Cow Game".

This is an ancient game similar to Mancala, and it originated in Africa, in the area now known as the Sudan.

The board is similar to a Mancala board, and 5 stones are placed in each of the 10 playing wells. Players take turns moving stones by picking up all the stones in a well (except for one!) then dropping a stone in each well until they run out, moving either clockwise or counter-clockwise. You skip the scoring wells and must put a stone in the well you started in (in addition to leaving one there to begin the move). A well with only a single stone cannot be moved.

After your move, starting with the well you last placed a stone into, any wells that have exactly two or four stones may be placed in your scoring well. If there is a well that you cannot score (it has a number of stone other than 2 or 4), then any that come after it in sequence may not be scored either.

The game ends when neither player can make a legal move. Any stones left on a players side of the board are added to those in his scoring well. However has the most stones is the winner.

15450.name: Strategy Poker
15450.description:
From the rules of the game:

"There are many variations of poker as it is played throughout the world but most require 6 or 7 players to have fun. Strategy Poker is great fun for 4 players, but 3 or 2 can play. Regular poker rules and etiquette apply and a knowledge of basic poker is required. As in most card games, 'Lady Luck' is still important but in this game, special emphasis is on skill and strategy."

Strategy Poker is a poker variant. The game consists of a deck of regular playing cards, betting chips, betting pot, and a viynl mat with places designated for card placement.

Players ante and then are dealt the "key card" and placed on the mat. Players will use the key card to build three independent poker hands all extending from the "key card." Essentially, players will ultimately be dealt cards and will try to create the best three five card hands from them. All hands will have the "key card" as part of it. Throughout the next four rounds player alternately bet and are dealt cards. The players must choose which card to place with each of their three hands. The player who is able to create the best five card poker hand wins the pot. To increase tension and bluffing, some cards are placed on the mat face down so opponents only get a glimpse as to what cards you have.

15451.name: Fresh Trax
15451.description:
Fresh Trax is a light “roll and move” type card game with a 3-D board and a snowboarding theme.

From the publisher’s web site: “Check out FreshTrax, the new board game from the makers of the HuckDoll. Take the lifts up, then ride through the trees, hike to higher ground or hit the terrain park. But be sure to collect a FreshTrax card on the way, cause you need one to win. Your FreshTrax card isn't all that safe anyway, cause your friends can pass you and take it away!”

From the back of the box: “Fresh Trax the board game captures the excitement of downhill skiing and snowboarding in a box. Shred your way through awesome terrain, including high traverse, hiking across, and a miniature terrain park. Race across the entire mountain, draw LIFT and TRAIL action cards, and be the first in your group to finish with Fresh Trax.”

Components:
Trail Map
Spinning Board
Ski & Snowboard Spinner
Ski & Snowboard Playing Pieces
6 3-D Inserts (mountains and terrain park that mount onto the game board, similar to The Game of Life)
Lift Cards
Trail Cards
Lift Die

Rules in brief:
Draw Lift cards to get up the mountain. At the top of the lift, pick a trail to ride down, then pick Trail cards to determine what actions happen to you on your way down the hill. Win by drawing a Fresh Trax card and getting back to the finish line first.

15452.name: Dicey
15452.description:
A dexterity game where players take turns stacking cards and dice.

Players take turns drawing a card. They then place dice on the card as to match the picture on the card. Finally the card is balanced on a communal stack in the middle of the table. Play continues to the next player.

When the stack collapses, the faulting player gains points from the sum of the top face of the dice touching the table. The game continues until one player earns 100 points, ending the game and making the player with the fewest points the winner.

Dicey comes with 22 dice and 13 cards.

15453.name: Rand McNally Destination: Vacation
15453.description:
Travel around the United States to various destinations using a mix of car, rail, ferry, or airplane. The objective is to be the first to collect 2 of each type of destination cards.

Destination cards are:
Blue - State Capitals
Green - Natural points of interest
Red - Historical sites
Purple - other points of interest.

Event cards are labeled "Play Now" or "Play Now or Later".

To begin a play selects a home city (one of Atlanta, Denver, Seattle, Los Angeles, Dallas, New York, Chicago). Draw a card for the first destination for the player.

Each turn a play may chose to move by one of the following:
Car - move using the solid dots i.e. a highway - the number of spaces on the sum of 2 dice.
Ferry - is like a highway except over the water between 2 cities.
Rail - move along the blue lines - 1 station for each even number on the 2 dice.
Air - Use a spinner (which has a 40/60 chance of success) to any other airport. If your plan is not at the airport where you are, you first need to use the spinner to get the plane to you and in a later move go to the other airport.

When travelling by car, rail, or ferry the player rolls a 3rd die; an even number allows you to move either you or any opponent, while an odd number you can only move yourself.

If you roll doubles when moving by car, rail, or ferry you must take an event card; Play Now cards are played immediately before you move, Play Now or Later cards can be played immediately or held onto for later.

Once you reach your first destination - you must either return to your home base to get a new card, or you can "phone home" (remember this was the 80's) using the same airplane spinner to get a new card.

15454.name: Riket
15454.description: Swedish trivia game based on a TV-show. Questions in six time periods.

15455.name: Värsta Språket
15455.description: Based on Swedish tv-show where the players try to imitate different dialects and play with words and expressions

15456.name: Arns rike
15456.description: You play the Swedish knight Arn Magnusson. The game lets you discover how life was in the 11th century.

15457.name: Melodi festival
15457.description:
The game is named after the Swedish version of the Eurovision song contest. The players are divided into teams with two participants in each team. Each teams playing piece advance along a track witch determines their action on a turn. These actions can be singing, charades or suchlike.
Should a team’s succeed in their task they are awarded a letter. They can then score points by writing answers beginning with that letter, to categories drawn at the beginning of the game, on their scoring sheets. Each correct answer scores one point.
The game is mostly memory based and rewards players that are knowledgeable about music.

15458.name: Gladiatorerna
15458.description:
Based on the Swedish version of the TV show "American Gladiators", where the players compete in different activities.

The game is for 2-4 players and is played out over 7 rounds, each one represented by a different minigame. In a two-player game the players take turns being the challenger or the gladiator. If the challenger defeats the gladiator in a turn they get markers/points which are used in the last turn. The winner of the last turn is the winner of the entire game.


The different minigames


Gatloppet (The Gauntlet)

In the Gauntlet the challenger tries to outwit the gladiator, while the gladiator tries to predict the challenger's next move. The challenger starts the game by picking cards of two different types. They then play one card at a time, the gladiator trying to match them. The challenger gets to move forward every time the gladiator fails to predict which card the challenger played. If the challenger gets to the finish line before running out of cards, they have won the round and get points depending on how many cards they have left in hand.

Duellen (The Duel, orig. Joust)

The Duel is a card based color matching game where the players simultaneously try to build ladders by combining cards with the same colored symbols on them. The game ends when one player can't continue their ladder. Points are awarded depending on how many cards are left in the player's hand, less than 5 yielding the maximum score. The challenger won't get any points if the gladiator finishes their ladder first.

Ringarna (The Rings, orig. Hang Tough)

The Rings is a tactical challenge played out in six turns. The challenger must move over to the gladiator's space or reach one of the eight scoring squares by playing movement cards. The gladiator's role is to catch the challenger by ending up on their space or to prevent them from reaching the score tiles by blocking their path.

Väggen (The Wall)

In the Wall the challenger tries to reach the top before time runs out or the gladiator catches them. It is played out over seven rounds. In each round the challenger calls out how many spaces they want to move in that turn. They then spin a spinner numbered 1 to 12. The challenger gets to move if the spinner shows the same number or higher. In round 4 the gladiator takes up the chase following the same movement rules but using the gladiator's spinner numbered 4 to 15. The minigame ends after seven rounds or after the challenger has either been caught or reached the top.

Rekylen (Recoil, orig. Snapback)

In Recoil the challenger tries to steal markers from the game board by moving their piece to the desired color. To accomplish this they must have the correct colored card in their hand. If they don't they can chose to play the card turned face down and spin the spinner to try to get the correct color. The gladiator then tries to respond with the same colored card or by spinning the spinner to the same color in order to protect the marker. The minigame is over when the gladiator has played all of their cards.

Attackboll (Attack Ball, orig. Powerball)

In Powerball the challenger tries to place cardboard chits in the receiver by balancing them on a cardboard "spoon". The gladiator has a slightly larger "spoon" with which they try to block the challenger. The minigame ends when the time runs out.

Hinderbanan (The Obstacle Course, orig. The Eliminator)

The Obstacle Course is the final minigame, the winner takes it all. Players take turns trying to match symbols on a track by turning over cardboard tokens, a bit like Memory. The player with the most points from previous minigames starts and gets a number of markers equal to the difference between the players' scores. That player gets to keep turning over tokens until they fail. If they fail and have no markers remaining, the next player gets to start turning over pieces to try to match their symbols. If they do have any markers, they discard one and keep turning over tokens until they are out of markers. The player who first matches all of their symbols wins the entire game.

15459.name: Eva & Adam
15459.description: This game of "life, buddies and love" very loosely ties into a Swedish comic of the same name aimed at pre-teens. Before playing, all players write down their answers to some "embarrassing question" and these are placed in an envelope. During play, the roll of a die and movement of a communal piece determines what happens in a round. Activities include charades (get points for making the other players guess which persona you're acting out a particular scene as), trivia (everyone can get a point for answering a true-or-false question), a personal question (you get a point just for giving an answer), nothing (because there's nothing like losing your turn), and arbitrary events such as gaining points or losing your next turn (because there's nothing like effectively losing two turns). Once someone has 19 points they win and get to look at the answers in the envelope before anyone else.

15461.name: Got'cha!
15461.description: This "hot potato" type game features a plastic ball and chain. The ball has tiny feet on the bottom that act as a base, and a policeman (a cartoonish lion) sticking out of the top. The chain has a handcuff at the end that easily slips on and off a person's wrist. To play, you slip the handcuff onto your wrist and push the Policeman down into the ball to start the timer. The clock starts ticking away as the Policeman slowly rises out of the ball. You then roll the dice until "two" keys are tossed. If only one die shows a key, re-roll the second die until a key comes up. When two keys are rolled, you are free to remove the cuff and pass it to the next player who must put it on and roll the dice and so on around the table. When the timer stops, the Policeman pops up and the player wearing the cuff is eliminated. The last player left in the game wins.

15462.name: Get Nifty
15462.description:
Get Nifty the Sluggy Freelance card game is coming out in 2005. Play in the Sluggyverse with all your favorite characters. Get safe, get weird, Get Nifty!

Illustrated by Pete Abrams. Loved by all.

15463.name: Guinness Book of World Records Game
15463.description: This game, based on the famous book, is different from the 1975 version. You move along the board landing on Record Spaces. Some require a simple dice roll to break; for example, on "Mostest Eating Baked Beans" you roll 3 dice (1 red and 2 white) and if the red die is the highest of the 3 dice you break the record. If, however, you land on a Longest, Shortest, or Highest Record space, you must use the "Record Maker". This is a shuffleboard device where you flick a disk down a track with numbers on it. If you set or break the record using it, the Scorekeeper writes down the number so other players will know what score to beat. When you break a record you receive the Record Card for that space - either from the Scorekeeper, or the player currently holding the card. The first player to reach the END HERE space with at least 5 Record Cards is the winner.

15464.name: Gum Guys
15464.description: In this bizarre game, you take a "Silly Putty" like substance and use a mold to shape it into a Gum Guy. Plastic feet, arms and a hook on the head are inserted into the Guy and you hang it from a bar at the back of a plastic desk (gum under the desk, get it?). On your turn, you roll a die which instructs you to either add (or remove) weights to yours, or your opponent's Guy. As weights are added, the Guys begin to stretch downwards. The player whose Guy hits the ground first loses.

15465.name: Movie Star
15465.description: Trivia game with 2400 questions on movies.

boardgamehonor.9292: 2005 Årets Spill Best Party Game Nominee

15470.name: Anker spill
15470.description: The players place a plastic ring on their nose which has a line with an anchor on it. You then try to catch small rings which are placed on the table with the anchor.

15471.name: Kokkelimonke Jubileum
15471.description:
"Balderdash Double" is basically two games in one box; the Tactic editions of Beyond Balderdash and original Balderdash. Questions and answers have been shifted to the same side of the cards to make room for 5 words and definitions on the other side, to be played with the original Balderdash rules; one side of the board is exactly the same as in Tactic's previous version of Absolute/Beyond Balderdash, while the other side has simply 17 empty spaces and a start space for original Balderdash scoring. The spinner provided now has two sectored circles, one for use with Beyond/Absolute, the other with original. Includes 4800 questions.

Re-implements:

Balderdash
Beyond Balderdash

15472.name: Happy Day
15472.description: This is a simple card game with a "Crazy Eights" type mechanic. The object is have the happiest day. There is a board with 9 play areas. Chips are placed above the areas with their point values face down. Each player receives 5 cards. To start, you play a Yucky Day card (such as "Fly in your cereal...") onto the first area and inform any other player that he or she will experience the yucky event shown. That player must then try to match the card with either another Yucky Day card of the same color and number, or a Happy Day card which is wild. A new player is called on who again must match the new card. The first called on player who cannot make a match loses the round and must take the chip for that area. New cards are then dealt out for the next round and players play them into the next area. When all 9 rounds have been played, the player with the lowest point value on all of his or her chips had the happiest day and wins.

15473.name: Screenplay
15473.description: Screenplay: The game of movie "quotes" This game is similar to Trivial Pursuit, but uses movie quotes in the categories of action/adventure, comedies, dramas, musicals, westerns, horror, etc... Testing your knowledge of the most popular movies. You listen to a quote and answer which movie it came from, the actor or actress who said it or the character they portrayed. You move forward with each correct question answered, first to the finish wins.

15474.description: Polish card game for two players. One of the players is the Zombies, the second one - humans. Objective of the Zombies is to eat the people, but people want to save their own lives, which is possible if they survive until the sunrise. Game with humor and strategy.
15474.name: Zombiaki

15475.name: Allegiance
15475.description: Allegiance is a pretty interesting spin on Chess, Checkers and Backgammon. This game adds a third player to all three games, making for some interesting play on these classic games. From the game box: With the addition of a third player and the greatly expanded gameboard, Allegiance provides new and challenging dimensions to the classic games of chess, checkers and backgammon. Each of the three players may compete individually, or two players may form a temporary "allegiance" to defeat the third player. But beware of betrayal, there can be but one winner!

15476.name: ANSA: Mission to Alpha Centauri
15476.description:
It is January 14, 1972. You are the commander of an ANSA Icarus interstellar exploration spacecraft. Along with your fellow crew of three astronauts, your mission is to be the first human beings to travel to the nearest star system of Alpha Centauri. To do so, your spacecraft will travel at the speed of light on a ten year round trip mission.

ANSA scientist Dr. Otto Hasslein has theorized that there is an anomaly or "orphaned space" near Alpha Centauri where gravity and light bend to create a time warp. This can cause a spacecraft to experience a distortion in both time and distance. This phenomena has been referred to as a “Hasslein curve” and is just one of many hazards that interstellar space voyagers will have to contend with.

The objective of this game is to be the first ANSA spacecraft to travel to the star system of Alpha Centauri and return safely to Earth in the year 1982. Steer clear of a Hasslein curve to avoid a time warp. Game includes a frame able 14”x14” professionally printed one-fold gaming board, (4) "Icarus" spacecraft pawns, (4) plastic stands, (40) "Event" cards, (16) "Navigation" cards, spinner, instructions and box.

15477.name: The Boston Game
15477.description:
In this game you use a map of Boston’s subway to be the first to visit 6 "places of interest", which were cards drawn in the beginning of the game, and be the first to your home base to win. Movement is dice driven through the subway. This game has 36 "Places of Interest" cards, which are very informative to anyone who has any interest in Boston’s landmarks or attractions. The game board is a subway map of Boston. This game is a nice timepiece of the city of Boston circa 1973.

Sibling: The London Game
Sibling: The New York Game

15478.name: Happy Landing
15478.description: This is a simple track game with an airplane theme. On your turn, you spin the spinner and advance the number of spaces indicated. If you land on a space marked "Radio", you must move in the direction of the arrow in the next space beyond. You always move your piece along the level (altitude) it is on unless a space directs you to do otherwise. The first player to reach the space marked "Happy Landing Field" wins the game.

15479.name: Koops Hoops
15479.description: This is a dexterity finger flicking game that simulates a game of basketball. Each person (or team of two people) take turns flicking "ball" toward opponents "basket." Each team is giving 2 flicks per turn. Rules for regular scoring: 3-point shots, foul shots, and even slam dunks!

15480.name: Zig-Zag Zoom
15480.description: Each player takes their turn rolling their colored balls, one at a time. Players attempt to make their ball zigzag around scoring holes in an attempt to have it drop in the hole farthest to the end. Scoring holes range in point value as follows: 1, 2, 3, 5, and 10. A gutter around the sides is worth no points for those who roll their balls with too much speed. It takes skill and practice, or a lot of luck to score 10 points in one roll. Player with the most points after 5 rounds is the winner.

15481.name: Hardy Boys Game
15481.description: This game is based on the animated TV adventure series. Players try to solve the mystery of the Golden Idol by aiding the Hardy Boy's father-detective. On your turn, you roll the dice and move along the blue-circle path the number thrown. If you land on one of the 4 large blue circles you draw a card, and if it matches the color of your pawn, you keep it. Placing all 4 of your color cards together forms a picture of the Golden Idol. The first player to "restore" the idol wins the game.

15482.name: Political Assets
15482.description:
Heavily inspired by Monopoly (Roll/move, land on properties which you can buy, etc.), in Political Assets players attempt to accumulate wealth and public opinion in a bid to become President. From the game summary:

"The object of Political Assets is to rise from the ranks of an everyday taxpayer to become President of the United States...to win the game you must own all the property (wealth) and accumulate 60% of the public opinion.

"The game was designed to show that in politics one must strive to move by attaining property and public opinion. It must be noted that in being to quick the person may become bankrupt or impeached from the group. On the other hand, if too slow another person will beat you to your goal. You may also make deals as well as most politicians do, however, please keep the deals related to both sides all inclusive to the game components only."

15483.name: Middle East Battles: Suez '56
15483.description:
The Middle East Battles: Suez '56 & El Arish '67, are two games in one that depict an operational simulation of mid-20th century warfare in and near the Sinai peninsula. Both games in the system represent, in two-player format, a clash between two or more of the important military powers in that region during the middle third of that century. The playing pieces represent the actual units that participated, or could have participated, in those battles, and the maps show the militarily significant terrain over which the units fought or could have fought.

Suez '56 simulates the Anglo-French invasion of Egypt at the time of the 1956 Arab-Israeli War. The Anglo-French objectives were to seize the Suez Canal, which the Egyptians had nationalized, and to possibly also overthrow the regime of Gamel Abd El Nasser. Though the invaders gain their military objectives, they unleashed a political disaster on themselves when the United States joined the Soviet Union in condemning the operation.

Published in Strategy & Tactics magazine #226 - Jan/Feb 2005.

Game Scale:
Game Turn: 6-8 hours
Hex: 360 yards / 329 meters
Units: Company to Battalion

Game Inventory:
One 22 x 34" full color mapsheet
One dual-side printed countersheet (280 1/2" counters - 101 for Suez '56, 110 for El Arish '67, 30 errata/variant for The East is Red, 39 errata/variant for Dixie)
One 16-page Middle East Battles rulebook

Solitaire Playability: High
Complexity Level: Medium
Players: 2 or more
Playing Time: 2-10 Hours

15484.description:
The Middle East Battles: Suez '56 & El Arish '67, are two games in one that depict an operational simulation of mid-20th century warfare in and near the Sinai peninsula. Both games in the system represent, in two-player format, a clash between two or more of the important military powers in that region during the middle third of that century. The playing pieces represent the actual units that participated, or could have participated, in those battles, and the maps show the militarily significant terrain over which the units fought or could have fought.

The El Arish '67 battle game simulates the initial Israeli onslaught into the Sinai, which led to their spectacular triumph over the Egyptians a few days later. This opening battle could've gone much better for the Egyptians. They had actually planned a strong mechanized counterattack, but their high command lost their nerve at the last moment and ordered a general withdrawal instead. In the game, the Egyptian player has both those options available to him.

Published in Strategy & Tactics magazine #226 - Jan/Feb 2005.

Game Scale:
Game Turn: 6 hours
Hex: 1 mile / 1.6 kilometer
Units: Company to Brigade

Game Inventory:
One 22 x 34" full color mapsheet
One dual-side printed countersheet (280 1/2" counters - 110 for El Arish '67, 101 for Suez '56, 30 errata/variant for The East is Red, 39 errata/variant for Dixie)
One 16-page Middle East Battles rulebook

Solitaire Playability: High
Complexity Level: Medium
Players: 2 or more
Playing Time: 2-10 Hours
15484.name: Middle East Battles: El Arish '67

15485.name: Have Gun Will Travel
15485.description: This game is based on the television adventures of the famed "Paladin" who accepts assignments to capture outlaws of the Old west. Each player is dealt a card depicting an outlaw, the city he's located in and reward amount for capturing him. On your turn, you spin the spinner and advance along the trails the number of spaces indicated. When you reach the town where the outlaw on your card is located, you immediately spin the spinner and if it stops on "HIT", you capture the outlaw (otherwise you try again next turn). Once captured, you place a "Bullet" token on the card then draw a new one. If you land on another player, you may have a shootout (high spin wins) and the loser has an outlaw escape. The first player to return to San Francisco with the required amount of money ($15,000 with 4 players) by capturing outlaws wins.

15486.name: Bankerott
15486.description: Each player has a pot of gold which you have to defend from the other players attack. This is done by placing number and action cards on the table. Whoever gets all the gold wins.

15487.name: Examen
15487.description: Trivia game where each card contains 2 right and 4 wrong statements. In 30 seconds you have to pick the right ones.

15488.name: Official Skins Golf Game
15488.description: The object of this game is to get the least amount of strokes and the most amount of Token$. Every hole is worth at least one token from every player. The player must win the hole outright in order to collect the token from green. If two or more players tie on a hole with the lowest score, the hole is a "Push" and all tokens will be carried forward to the next hole. Remember there is an ante of 1 token for each hole, and every players gets the opportunity to win all carry overs.

15490.name: Geni
15490.description:
Geni (Genius) is a classic trivia game in Norway. Since its original release in 1986, the game has been re-released about every three years, and has also been remade in different themes.

The current rules have been fixed since the second edition (1993), and the game consits of three stages:

1st stage: Answer (at least) one question from each category correctly
2nd stage: Answer two questions from two categories dictated by the board (depending on which route you choose to the center)
3rd stage: Answer one question from a category decided by the player to the left

The first player to complete the last stage wins.

List of editions:


1986 (528 cards with 3168 questions): Had different 2nd and 3rd stages. (The last stage was answering three questions correctly IN SUCCESSION)
1989 Released as Geni: Pop & Rock
1993 (400 cards). The current rules were settled. Categories: Geography, Sports and Entertainment, Nature and Science, 1 X 2 (multiple choice), History, and Mixed
1997 (500 cards) Categories: As in 1993 ed, but replaced 1 X 2 with Events from '96-97
1997 (132 cards) Expansion pack, also playable as stand-alone.
2000 (500 cards), named Gull Geni. Categories: As in 1993 ed, but replaced 1 X 2 with 20th Century, and Mixed with Modern Music
2003 (470 cards, plus 30 Stroke of Genius cards) Categories: As in 1993 ed, but replaced 1 X 2 with From 1900 to current time. (The stroke of genius cards is a joker category.)
2003 Travel edition
2005 New edition of Geni: Pop & Rock
2006 (376 cards, plus 24 Stroke of Genius cards) New categories: TV and Entertainment, Norway, Culture and History, Our world, Sports and Leisure, Mixed


Geni is also featured in a series of childrens editions.

15491.name: Guerre et Frontiere
15491.description:
The setting of this French game is a world populated with orcs, trolls and humans who fight to dominate the board.

Although the main mechanisms are quite ordinary, there are two outstanding features :
- all peoples build up hatred toward each other after each war. If too many clashes occur, before long war spreads everywhere.
- when fighting one of the two Evil Empires, a player must eat a treat called... the Troll's Dung ! This horrendous stuff was sold in-box, along with the recipe to cook more. So be cautious when you're looking for a fight !

15493.name: Jernteppe?!
15493.description: Trivia game with 3200 questions, where the questions are based on funny expressions.

15494.name: Jolle-VM
15494.description: Boat racing game where you make four laps on a sailing course. The three best placements counts as your total. During the race the players will try to answer questions on different sailing terms, flags and so on. A correct answer will give you an advantage in the race.

15496.name: Langrenns-VM
15496.description: Cross-country skiing game. Choose any distance between 5 and 50 KM, but be sure to pick the right equipment because the conditions might change during the course.

15497.description:
Variation on Monopoly but in this game there is a lot more chance cards, and you also have to buy the roads and the land for building houses.

Have the norwegian Monopoly chance card: "All your houses and hotels burns to the ground"
15497.name: Millionær

15498.name: Minuttmesterne
15498.description: By clue words, miming, drawing or forming in clay the players try to get their teammates to guess the assignment.

15499.name: Miracula
15499.description: As a wizard the players fill their cauldron with ingredients to make gold.

15500.name: Misjonsspillet
15500.description: The players set out to convert the peoples of the world as missionaries.
